Chiyu Workshop

Discover Healing with Sound, Art and Haiku Poetry

Saturday, April 21, 2012

 

Chiyu in Japanese means healing, cure and recovery. On Saturday, April 21 from 1 – 4 p.m. the Buddhist Faith Fellowship and NEIBS will be offering a unique workshop with three distinct but related events: sound healing meditation to help transform negative energy blocks that cause disease, an origami peace crane making session with the goal of offering these symbols of hope and harmony to those in need and a haiku poetry writing session to express inner hope and Renewal.

 

This Chiyu Workshop will take place at the Mansfield Freeman Center of East Asian Studies, FEAS Room, 343 Washington Terrace, Middletown, Ct, $5 donation is requested for supplies. For more information email the event’s coordinator at mpetersson@wesleyan.edu

 

About Sound Healing - Sound healing transforms one's vibrations to a higher frequency. With mantras, awareness increases and can bring healingopportunities into one's life that one wasn't aware of before. Tuning the chakras helps balance our energy systems. Energy blocks are what cause disease. The everyday stresses that we experience cause energy blockages. It is a powerful tool to help clear these blockages.                                                                                              

 

About Origami Peace Cranes - The origami paper crane became an international symbol of peace because a young Japanese girl, dying of leukemia after the bombing of Hiroshima, made 1000 paper cranes before she died to express her desire for peace. Thus, making cranes have become a way to offer hope and harmony to those in special need.

 

To register online for this special event, you may do so online below or at the door.

 

Register at the door or online at http://dharmaquest.bffct.net or email mpetersson@wesleyan.edu
